title: Zip It! - Finding File Similarity Using Compression Utilities - Computerphile
description:
Finding Genome similarity can just be a case of zipping the relevant files in the right order. Buck Shlegeris is CEO of Redwood Research

Papers: 
https://homepages.cwi.nl/~paulv/papers/similarity.pdf
https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC9030035/#sec4-entropy-24-00439

Computerphile is supported by Jane Street. Learn more about them (and exciting career opportunities) at: https://jane-st.co/computerphile

This video was filmed and edited by Sean Riley.

Computerphile is a sister project to Brady Haran's Numberphile. More at https://www.bradyharanblog.com

comments.author: @FusionDeveloper
comments.comment:
Right, so if you have a text file that is a billion pages long and every character is a single letter repeated with no spaces and you zip this, 
it will shrink down to practically nothing, 
because the zip can basically say "replace the entire document with text that says: 99999 billion letter 'a' ". which could all fit in 1 line of the document.

comments.author: @j7ndominica051
comments.comment: You need a dictionary that fits all the data or at least a bit bigger than the first file. Zip isn't gonna cut it. It's possible to transpose the second file with a simple arithmetic operation that the compressor won't recognize. I am skeptical that a "genome" can provide a pristine data that is directly similar to another copy. Isn't it a bit "noisy" coming from the outside world? The genome is said to contain unused bits of code.

comments.comment: Of course, with window sizes, naively gzipping / deflating will not necessarily give the desired results for files more than about 30kB in size (basically it'd be comparing the last ~30kB of the first file to the first ~30kB of the second file).

comments.author: @bmx666bmx666
comments.comment: It's a delta compression. Check command-line tool "xdelta3" which compares two binaries and outputs their difference. You can store and share just one initial file and generate deltas for other files from it. This is a popular tool for reducing storage space by saving only diff snapshots between firmware images for devices. The same algorithm is used in OTA updates for devices with A/B system images. Instead of downloading complete new system image, the OTA updater clones system A to system B and applies binary diff patch.

comments.author: @ryanfranz6715
comments.comment: 3:30, that’s a pretty good phylogenetic tree… I think though primates (and humans) are more closely related to rodents (like rats) than they are to canivorans (like cats) and cloven-hooved ungulates (including whales). Our last ancestor between human and rat lived 75 million years ago, vs 85 million years for the last ancestor between humans and cats. Minor caveat but still impressed how well that worked because you’re literally just zipping the genomes.

comments.author: @KevinHorecka
comments.comment: Ok so say you have some data that you think might be an alien communication. You have vanishingly little prior knowledge of what it might say or how it might be encoded. You take chunks of human data of a similar size - ALL sorts of data - and you get a similarly distribution. Then you do the same thing for noise. How would you decide how much and of what type of data to use for this to claim a signal is "significantly more human-like" than random (we'll go ahead and assume they're not using alien cryptography to make it look intentionally random)?

comments.author: @Tony-dp1rl
comments.comment: This video incorrectly explains why it works. ZIP compression uses a sliding dictionary window (e.g., 32KB), so when the second file is appended, the beginning of the first file is no longer in the dictionary. It doesn’t just "reuse" the first file. Zip compression relies on local repetition, so the effect is really about comparing the entropy of the files, which also works, but not for the reasons outlined in this video.

comments.author: @MonochromeWench
comments.comment: Doing this for languages will bias towards grouping languages with shared vocabulary rather than shared grammar. Languages like English that have a lot of loan words will get grouped incorrectly. Compression works on the characters of the text and not the more abstract sentence structure and how different types of words are grouped together.

comments.author: @ujjawalsinha8968
comments.comment: There was a paper in 2022 titled: Less is More: Parameter-Free Text Classification with Gzip, which uses this exact text distance formula with KNN for text classification, and claimed that it was on par with Bert models (.. it was not)

comments.author: @Haimitlasern
comments.comment: Your method classified English as a Romance language!

comments.author: @vylbird8014
comments.comment:
Ugh... you know this is going N-squared when you're doing a lot of comparisons? Fine, here's what you do:
1. Rabin chunk your data to chop it up into sections in a manner that won't be thrown off by insertion or deletion.
2. Take each chunk. Hash it. Now each file is represented by a set of hashes.
3. Jaccard distance each pair of sets of hashes.

There, much faster.

comments.comment: No, compression is not intelligence. It is related but not the same. Intelligence does tend to compress input but not all compressions are the same. If you know about the data generator, you can compress more efficiently. When you do so, you are incorporating knowledge. The ability to do so is intelligence.

comments.author: @tristanwegner
comments.comment: Ilya Sutskever also commented on the similarity between compression and intelligence. Just think about how much data would be needed to document als the positions of the planet of the past, but with some intelligence, we found a very smaller way to express the timeline of them via Keplers laws, so you just needed the few short formulas and the position of the planet at only one moment, to calculate is for all the other times.

comments.author: @tristanwegner
comments.comment: but must be the right compression algorithm that actually finds repetitions multiple megabytes away! I guess some algorithm only search for them on the higher compression settings, which are often not used, because compression takes MUCH longer, and many files don't get relevantly smaller.

comments.author: @user-qf6yt3id3w
comments.comment: 2:52 I see the theory but doesn't this depend on the window size used in the compression? Gzip uses a 32KB window size. The human genome is about 3 billion base pairs. You gave four base pairs so you need 2 bits to encode each one, or 4 per byte. So it's about a gigabyte of data. You'd need a 1GB window for this to work.

comments.author: @jarlsparkley
comments.comment: I like that this technique identifies English as a romance language. I think that he makes a mistake when he identifies this as an imperfect depiction of the history of these languages. In my opinion, what he’s doing perhaps without realizing it is demonstrating that there’s other useful ways of classifying things other than what is considered canonical or conventional.

comments.comment: Neat!  Something I had never considered..

comments.author: @aronhidman1
comments.comment: A file full of random noise would compress to the basically the same size. But noise has zero complexity: maximum entropy (and very complicated) but no information content, so no complexity. So it's not really true in all cases that the size of the compressed file is a measure of complexity.

If anyone is interested, the work is by Vogel et. al. and the compressor is called wlzip
